Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Plasmofluidic Nanoantenna-Superlens Biosensor for Single-Cell Functional Immunophenotyping

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate and real-time analysis of the functions of different disease-fighting blood cells is very useful for monitoring the immune status of the human body, as well as evaluating the disease stage and drug efficacy. The objective of this research is to develop a new method that enables single-cell functional immune analysis from droplets of human blood. Such a platform would ultimately provide clinicians a new measurement for quantitatively characterizing the disease-fighting blood cells. The proposed educational plans will have broad impacts on students from various educational levels (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate), genders, and ethnicities.

Accurate and real-time analysis of the functions of different immune cell subsets is needed for monitoring the immune status of patients, as well as for evaluating the disease stage and drug efficacy. In particular, quantitative and dynamic profiling of the cytokine secretions from individual immune cells is useful for determining the cellular functional immune phenotype in patients. However, the heterogeneity of the immune cells makes such quantitative characterization challenging especially when dealing with human blood samples. The objective of this research is to develop a new integrated plasmofluidic nanoantenna-superlens biosensing platform that enables single-cell, multi-subset, multiplex functional immune analysis from microliters of human blood. The approach combines an efficient on-chip single immune cell isolation technique and a parallel cell cytokine secretion assay based on the label-free plasmonic nanoantenna-superlens biosensor. The proposed research will be achieved by pursuing the following objectives. 1) development of plasmonic nanoantenna-superlens biosensing platform for rapid and sensitive on-chip cytokine detection; 2) development of microfluidic single cell isolation technique to achieve purification of leukocyte subsets from a heterogeneous mixture found in whole blood; and 3) demonstration of an integrated plasmofluidic nanoantenna-superlens barcode microarray biosensor for multiplex functional immunophenotyping of single immune cells. The analysis performed using the proposed platform for a large number of individual immune cells will establish a new approach that permits immunophenotypical screening of leukocyte subsets by detecting differences and time-dependent variations of their immune functions. Such a platform would ultimately provide clinicians a new tool for quantitatively characterizing the immunophenotypes of patients and would, therefore, allow precise disease diagnosis, monitoring, and risk stratification. The proposed educational plan will have broad impacts on students from different educational levels (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate), genders, and ethnicities. Technologies developed in the proposal will be used as effective vehicles for education and outreach activities. Extending research opportunities to K-12 students and undergraduates will expose them to the rewarding scientific discoveries and encourage them to pursue future studies and careers in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established novel label-free, ultra-sensitive, high-throughput nanoplasmonic sensing platforms for real-time cytokine detection. Since the sensing performance of the proposed biosensor is highly dependent on the optical properties of nanomaterials, a variety of new nanoplasmonic structures, such as gold nano-diamond, gold/silver core/shell bipyramids, iron oxide/gold and iron oxide/copper core shell structures and nanoplasmon ruler were successfully synthesized. The effects of size, shape and composition on the sensing performance of these nanomaterials were investigated. Based on these novel nanostructures, a magnet assisted array patterning technique for iron oxide/gold core shell nanoparticles was developed. This method allows easy fabrication of uniform, self-assembled nanomaterial microarray in a large surface area. The nanomaterial microarray was used as a biosensor that can perform real-time detection of four cytokines in human serum with high sensitivity, selectivity, and statistical accuracy.

The developed label-free cytokine biosensors were also applied to understand the immune responses induced by protein aggregation associated with a range of metabolic and brain diseases. The unique advantage of these nanoplasmonic biosensor in real-time cytokine detection enables dynamic study of interactions between immune cells and amyloid protein aggregates in a biologically relevant microenvironment. The results show great importance of real-time biosensing technologies in comprehensive analysis of protein-nanoparticle induced immune response and provide new insights and direction for the future design of nanomedicines for amyloid diseases. 

In addition, a nanoplasmonic cytokine biosensor was integrated with a microfluidic system that enables on-chip cell culture in a complex biomimetic microenvironment and quantitative analysis of cytokine secretion over time. The integrated device was applied to measure the dynamic secretion profile during adipocyte differentiation in an adipose tissue microenvironment. The results demonstrate the unique capability of the integrated biosensor platform for identifying cytokine secretion at specific disease stage and its great potential for preclinical readout for personalized obesity treatment strategies.

All the work done in this project has shown great promise of the integrated microfluidic cytokine biosensors for the study of immune functional responses and the intercommunication with other systems. We performed a review on the most recent progress in label-free cytokine detection based on localized surface plasmon resonance optical sensing. We presented the applications of newly identified plasmonic nanostructures and the integration with advanced microfluidic devices for novel lab-on-a-chip biosensing systems (shown in image) and discussed the associated challenges and future perspective of such integrative sensing technologies for next generation immune functional analysis.

Over the entire project period, nine peer-reviewed journal papers have been published. Eight conference presentations and other invited research talks have been delivered. Twelve master students successfully defended their degree. Two undergraduate students participated in the project and continued their graduate study.
